questions.text: A vegan lady came with features of anemia. She is likely to have deficiency of: ( FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Vitamin B12

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Vegans, who follow a diet that excludes all animal products, are at a higher risk of developing vitamin B12 deficiency. Vitamin B12, also known as cobalamin, is primarily found in animal-derived foods such as meat, dairy products, and eggs. Since vegans do not consume these foods, they are prone to developing vitamin B12 deficiency, which can lead to anemia.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Vitamin D deficiency is not specifically related to a vegan diet. While vegans may need to supplement vitamin D from non-animal sources, the question does not provide enough information to suggest that this is the likely deficiency.
  • • Option A. Vitamin D
  • • Option C. Vitamin A deficiency is also not directly related to a vegan diet. Vegans can obtain sufficient vitamin A from plant-based sources such as leafy green vegetables, carrots, and sweet potatoes.
  • • Option C. Vitamin A
  • • Option D. Vitamin C deficiency is unlikely in a vegan diet, as many fruits and vegetables are rich sources of vitamin C.
  • • Option D. Vitamin C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vegans are at a higher risk of developing vitamin B12 deficiency, which can lead to anemia, as vitamin B12 is primarily found in animal-derived foods.

questions.text: Which site is most commonly used for the initial biopsy to confirm a diagnosis of systemic amyloidosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Abdominal fat aspiration is commonly used as an initial biopsy site to diagnose systemic amyloidosis. The procedure is minimally invasive with low complication rates compared to other tissue biopsies. Examination of abdominal fat aspirates stained with Congo red can be used for the diagnosis of systemic amyloidosis. While the test is quite specific, its sensitivity is lower than more invasive biopsies, but it is still preferred as an initial diagnostic approach due to its safety profile.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Gingiva - While gingival biopsy can be used to diagnose amyloidosis, it is not typically the first-line approach. Gingival tissue is a possible site for biopsy in patients suspected of having systemic amyloidosis, but it is less commonly used than abdominal fat aspiration.
  • • Option A. Gingiva
  • • Option B. Kidney - Kidney biopsy is performed when there are renal manifestations of amyloidosis but is not used as the initial diagnostic procedure due to its invasive nature and potential complications. It is usually reserved for cases where kidney involvement is the primary concern or when less invasive methods are inconclusive.
  • • Option B. Kidney
  • • Option C. Rectal mucosa - Rectal mucosa biopsy can be used to diagnose systemic amyloidosis, but like gingival biopsy, it is not the first-line approach. It is more invasive than abdominal fat aspiration but may be performed when other sites yield inconclusive results.
  • • Option C. Rectal mucosa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Abdominal fat aspiration is the preferred initial diagnostic procedure for systemic amyloidosis due to its minimal invasiveness, relative safety, and good specificity, although other tissue sites including kidney, rectal mucosa, and gingiva may be biopsied depending on clinical presentation and when fat aspiration is inconclusive.

questions.text: Heavy chain disease associated with the presence of kappa light chains in the urine: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia (also called lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma) is characterized by production of IgM monoclonal protein and is associated with the presence of kappa light chains. In this condition, light chain (kappa) is produced in the same quantity as heavy chain (mu), which contrasts with other heavy chain diseases where there is predominant production of heavy chain antibody. The disease presents as an M spike of IgM type and commonly manifests with hyper viscosity syndrome due to the large size of IgM molecules.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Mu chain disease - This is incorrect. Mu (μ) chain disease is a rare heavy chain disease associated with CLL rather than with the presence of kappa light chains in urine. It involves the production of abnormal μ heavy chains without associated light chains.
  • • Option A. Mu chain disease
  • • Option B. Sezary disease - This is incorrect. Sezary syndrome is not a heavy chain disease but a variant of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma characterized by erythroderma, lymphadenopathy, and neoplastic T cells (Sezary cells) with cerebriform nuclei in the blood.
  • • Option B. Sezary disease
  • • Option C. Franklin disease - This is incorrect. Franklin disease (gamma heavy chain disease) is characterized by the production of gamma (γ) heavy chains without associated light chains. It presents with fever, lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, and is associated with rheumatoid arthritis, but not specifically with kappa light chains in urine.
  • • Option C. Franklin disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia is distinguished from other heavy chain diseases by the production of intact IgM molecules with balanced synthesis of heavy and light chains (including kappa light chains), often leading to hyper viscosity syndrome due to high levels of the large IgM protein.

questions.text: A patient displaying lytic lesions on the skull is being considered for a diagnosis of Langerhans cell histiocytosis. What represents a distinctive discovery on electron microscopy among the following options? ( INICET MAY 2023)

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented in OPD with complaints of fever, night sweats, and weight loss for 2 months. On examination, lymphadenopathy was present. questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1 and 2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about prasugrel? (NEET PG 2018)

options.label: A
options.text: It acts as an P2 Y12 agonist

options.label: B
options.text: It is 10 times less potent than clopidogrel

options.label: D
options.text: Omeprazole interferes with metabolism of prasugrel leading to increased risk of bleeding

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) It is a pro-drug

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Prasugrel is a pro-drug that, upon hepatic metabolism, becomes an active metabolite that irreversibly inhibits the P2Y12 ADP platelet receptors, thus preventing platelet aggregation and making it a potent antiplatelet agent.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presents to hospital with pain in great toe. His serum uric acid was raised. He was given a medication to relieve the pain and inflammation and after that, he was put on a drug for long term treatment of gout. Which of the following drug increases the excretion of uric acid in urine? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Probenecid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Probenecid is a uricosuric drug that increases the excretion of uric acid in the urine by inhibiting its reabsorption in the renal tubules. This makes it effective for the long-term management of gout by lowering serum uric acid levels. Other drugs like colchicine, allopurinol, and febuxostat have different mechanisms of action and do not increase uric acid excretion in the urine.

questions.text: Identify the anti-apoptotic factor among the following: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Bcl-2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bcl-2's anti-apoptotic properties make it a key player in cellular survival and stress response. Its ability to inhibit key steps in the apoptotic process distinguishes it from other proteins like P-53, K-ras, and BAK, which have different roles in the regulation of cell death and proliferation.
